answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-20-2.webp)

There is generalized thinning of the neurosensory retina in the foveal region with loss of the outer retinal layers (ONL, ELM, EZ, photoreceptors, RPE) and exaggerated foveal depression. Choroidal hyper-transmission (red box) is seen underneath the areas of thinning secondary to loss of RPE. There is no evidence of drusen on this OCT.

answers.answerText: A. Hyper-reflective deposits in the choroid
B. Migration of the RPE into the choroid

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-20-3.webp)

Choroidal hyper-transmission occurs due to increased signal penetration through areas of RPE loss. The area outlined in the red box denotes the choroidal hyper-transmission underneath the RPE.

![](/content/media/retina-20-3.webp)

The OCT demonstrates geographic atrophy, which is seen in late stages of AMD or any advanced macular pathology. Clinically, it appears as a well-demarcated area of hypopigmentation with RPE loss and visible choroidal vessels.

title: Case 20
description: 73F presenting with long-standing poor central vision OS
patientPresentation:
A 73-year-old female presents to ophthalmology clinic for a routine follow-up appointment. Her vision is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/400 in the left eye. Her central vision in the left eye has been poor for many years. An OCT macula was performed in the left eye demonstrating the following:
â€‹

![](/content/media/retina-20-1.webp)
footer:
### Learning Objectives:

1. Identify OCT features of geographic atrophy
2. Understand why choroidal transmission occurs in geographic atrophy
